blok_andere_gegevens.title: Other data
blok_andere_gegevens.message: Data that could give insight in the spread of the virus.

notificatie.bericht: The number of new persons that tested positive in the Netherland is increasing. The reproduction number is more than 1, just as it was last week.

link.text: View the recent information from the RIVM

error_beschrijving.text: Unfortunately something went wrong. Refresh the page or try again later.

header.title: Dashboard coronavirus
header.text: The coronavirus dashboard provides information on the development of the coronavirus in The Netherlands.

links.meer: More information on the corona virus

ic_opnames_per_dag.title: ICU admissions per day
ic_opnames_per_dag.text: Average number of daily admissions over the past 3 days
ic_opnames_per_dag.datums: Calculated on {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
ic_opnames_per_dag.fold: Number of confirmed COVID-19 patients admitted to a hospital intensive care unit (ICU) per day. This figure is an average for the daily admissions over the past three days.
ic_opnames_per_dag.screen_reader_graph_content: {{value}} intensive care-admissions per day. Alert value: {{signaalwaarde}} admissions per day.

verdenkingen_huisartsen.title: Number of patients who contact their GP for the first time because of symptoms associated with COVID-19
verdenkingen_huisartsen.text: Number of patients who contact their GP for the first time because of symptoms associated with COVID-19 per 100.000 inhabitants per week.
verdenkingen_huisartsen.datums: Value of  {{dateOfReport}}. Obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
verdenkingen_huisartsen.fold: General practitioners (GPs) record the reported and observed symptoms of the patients they see. Using this data, the Netherlands Institute for Health Services Research (NIVEL) calculates how many patients contacted their GP because of symptoms associated with COVID-19. Based on a sample of 350 GP's, the total amount is estimated for the entire Netherlands.
verdenkingen_huisartsen.screen_reader_graph_content: {{value}} Number of patients who contact their GP for the first time because of symptoms associated with COVID-19, per 100.000 inhabitants per week.

ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.title: Hospital admissions per day
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.text: Number of admissions per day, averaged over the past three days.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.datums: Calculated on {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.fold: Number of confirmed COVID-19 patients admitted to hospital per day. This number is an average for daily admissions over the past three days.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.screen_reader_graph_content: {{value}} Hospital admissions per day. Alert value: {{signaalwaarde}} admissions per day.

positief_geteste_personen.title: Positively tested persons
positief_geteste_personen.text: Number of positively tested persons per 100,000 inhabitants per day.
positief_geteste_personen.datums: Value of {{dateOfReport}}. Obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
positief_geteste_personen.fold: This figure shows how many people per 100,000 inhabitants were reported yesterday as testing positive for COVID-19.
positief_geteste_personen.graph_title: New cases by age group (total number of new cases)
positief_geteste_personen.graph_axis_title: Total number of positively tested persons

besmettelijke_personen.title: Number of infectious people
besmettelijke_personen.text: A calculation of how many people with COVID-19 per 100.000 inhabitants can transmit the virus.
besmettelijke_personen.datums: Value of {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
besmettelijke_personen.fold: A person who carries coronavirus can infect other people within a certain time frame. How long someone is infectious for differs from one person to another. The number of infectious people is estimated using data from various sources. It is not possible to know exactly how many people are infectious, but we can indicate whether there are dozens, hundreds, thousands or even more.
besmettelijke_personen.metric_title: Estimated number of infectious people in the Netherlands:
besmettelijke_personen.legenda_line: The number of infectious people in the Netherlands
besmettelijke_personen.legenda_marge: The confidence interval shows the range between which the number of infectious people falls.

reproductiegetal.title: Reproduction number
reproductiegetal.text: Number of people infected by one infectious person.
reproductiegetal.datums: Value of {{dateOfReport}}. Obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
reproductiegetal.fold: The reproduction number shows how fast the virus is spreading. The number shows how many people are on average infected by one patient with Covid019. The number of transmissions remains more or less constant when the reproduction number is 1, declines when it is less than 1 and increases when the number is above 1.
reproductiegetal.legenda_r: De effectieve R is een schatting. Voor recente R schattingen is de betrouwbaarheid niet groot, daarom loopt de R-lijn niet door in de laatste twee weken.
reproductiegetal.legenda_marge: The confidence interval shows the range between which the number R falls. This is updated on a weekly basis.

overige_gegevens.title: To be developed
overige_gegevens.text: We aim to expand the dashboard in the future with the following data:

list.content: The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) monitors the spread of infectious diseases, including COVID-19, in several different ways. One useful tool is the Infectionradar website, which allows RIVM to track the number of people with symptoms associated with a Covid-19 infection. Anyone in the Netherlands can participate in the infectionradar. Once a week participants report whether they have or have had a fever or any other symptoms, or no symptoms at all. This gives experts faster insight into whether the spread of the virus is increasing or decreasing.

list.text: Contact tracing by the municipal health service
list.content: When someone is infected with coronavirus, the municipal health service (GGD) tries to find out where they got it from and who they recently had contact with. The purpose is to discover whether the virus has also been transmitted to any other people.

Care professionals with COVID-19 can infect their patients, so monitoring care professionals’ health can help contain the spread of the disease. This means keeping track of the number of care professionals who are infected with coronavirus and the number who report ill. This data also helps the healthcare system cope with increases in workload.
Data on the movement of people can indicate how the coronavirus is spreading. The aim is to show this per muncipality.
The compliance monitor provides insight into the degree to which people are able to follow the coronavirus measures.

RIVM routinely collects data from behavioural studies that shed light on trends in compliance with and support for the basic rules that apply, like washing hands, staying home and getting tested if you have symptoms.

regio_link_block.title: Information per region
regio_link_block.text: View the most important information for your safety region.

verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.title: Number of infected locations
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.text: The number of new locations where at least on resident is tested postive per day.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.datums: Value of {{dateOfReport}}. Obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.metric_title: The total number of infected locations is:
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.metric_text: This figure is an estimate of the number of nursing homes where in the past 28 days at least one (new) Covid-19 infection (confirmed by a positive test) is reported.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.fold: This figure is an estimate of the number of nursing homes with a new COVID-19 outbreak following at least one positive test. The figure is for the number of nursing homes where a new outbreak was reported yesterday. A nursing home is considered to have a new outbreak if there had been no new cases of COVID-19 in the home in the previous 28 days (i.e. twice the length of the incubation period). Please note: the increase in the total number of infected nursing homes does not always match the daily number of newly infected locations. More information can be found in the explanation of the presented data.
verpleeghuis_besmette_locaties.screen_reader_graph_content: {{value}} new locations where at least one resident tested positive per day.

verpleeghuis_positief_geteste_personen.title: Number of positively tested residents
verpleeghuis_positief_geteste_personen.text: Number of positively tested residents in nursing homes per day
verpleeghuis_positief_geteste_personen.datums: Value of {{dateOfReport}}. Obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
verpleeghuis_positief_geteste_personen.fold: This value is an estimate of the daily number of nursing home residents in the Netherlands who tested positive for coronavirus and have COVID-19. The value refers to the day before the date on which it was most recently updated.

verpleeghuis_oversterfte.title: Death
verpleeghuis_oversterfte.text: Number of deceased residents in nursing homes with a confirmed Covid-19 infection per day.
verpleeghuis_oversterfte.datums: Value of  {{dateOfReport}}. Obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
verpleeghuis_oversterfte.fold: This number is an estimate of the number of nursing home residents in the Netherlands who died due to the coronavirus. The value refers to the date before the date of the last update.

blok_verpleeghuis_zorg.title: Nursing homes
blok_verpleeghuis_zorg.text: Information on the spread of the coronavirus in nursing homes.

geen_selectie.text: Select your region at the top of this page

rioolwater_metingen.title: Waste water testing
rioolwater_metingen.text: Het aantal virusdeeltjes in een milliliter rioolwater, afkomstig van 28 locaties in Nederland. Het aantal meetpunten wordt in de komende weken verder uitgebreid naar meer dan 300 locaties.
rioolwater_metingen.datums: Value of  {{dateOfReport}}. Obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
rioolwater_metingen.fold: In rioolwater kun je ziekteverwekkers zoals het nieuwe coronavirus meten omdat die met uitwerpselen (ontlasting) in het rioolwater komen. Onderzoekers testen eens per week rioolwater dat over 24 uur verzameld is. Dit onderzoek laat vrij snel zien hoeveel virusdeeltjes in het rioolwater zitten afkomstig uit uitwerpselen van besmette personen. Uit het huidige onderzoek kunnen nog geen conclusies worden getrokken. Het is de bedoeling dat het aantal meetpunten wordt uitgebreid van 28 naar meer dan 300 voor 1 september 2020. Pas als het onderzoek volledig loopt, kunnen hier conclusies aan worden verbonden.
rioolwater_metingen.screen_reader_graph_content: {{value}} viral particles in one milliliter of waste water, collected from 28 locations in the Netherlands.

notfound_beschrijving.text: Unfortunately something went wrong. Refresh the page or try again later.

over_disclaimer.title: Disclaimer
over_disclaimer.text: Please Note: this dashboard is still in the development phase. New features and data will be added to it in stages in the period ahead. Steps are also being taken to improve the website’s accessibility and user-friendliness. We want everyone in the Netherlands to be able to access the information on this website. The dashboard is not yet being used for decision-making. No conclusions can yet be made on the basis of the data presented here.

over_beschrijving.text: The coronavirus dashboard gives up-to-date information about the development of the coronavirus in the Netherlands. With this information  early signs that the rate of infection is increasing can be picked up. We must prevent losing control over the spread of the virus. The numbers of new intensive care (ICU) patients and hospital admissions are the ultimate warning, but early indications are provided by the results of testing people for the virus. These are used to calculate the number of people who are infected with coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) per 100,000 inhabitants. There are also other, secondary indicators to describe the course of the epidemic and give other information.

vragen.antwoord: The dashboard presents up-to-date information about the spread of coronavirus in the Netherlands. It uses data provided by the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM), municipal health services (GGDs), hospitals and other sources. The dashboard shows, for example, how many people tested positive for the virus and if the number of infected people is increasing. The dashboard is intended for everyone who wants a useful overview of the most up-to-date data.

Over the past several months, many people have become ill because of coronavirus and many people have died. Until there is an effective vaccine, the virus can easily flare up and again make large numbers of people ill. The dashboard shows if and where the virus is gaining ground. Using this information we can take control measures faster and in a more targeted way, such as introducing additional measures only in the regions with sharply increasing infection rates. Measures must always be based on a comprehensive political assessment of all relevant aspects, including broader social and economic interests.

The dashboard has been commissioned by the Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport. New types of data will be added to it in the weeks ahead. In the future, the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) will manage the dashboard.

The data currently presented on the dashboard gives the best overall view of the epidemiological situation. This data includes the number of people who have tested positive and the number of people admitted to hospital with COVID-19. Other data will be added to the dashboard shortly. Together they will give an accurate picture of the epidemic in the Netherlands.

vragen.vraag: The dashboard is still in development. What does this mean?
vragen.antwoord: In the near future, secondary data will be added to the main indicators already shown on the dashboard. It will also give an overview of all measures and public advice in place at both national and regional level.

An alert value is calculated by the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) and is intended to act as a warning. A warning can be triggered if a large number of people become ill or are admitted to hospital at the same time. According to RIVM’s models, the healthcare sector will be unable to cope if daily hospital admissions for COVID-19 exceed 40 per day for an extended period of time.

vragen.vraag: What can the regional overview tell that the national overview cannot?
vragen.antwoord: Coronavirus spreads easily among people. In recent months RIVM has identified several regional outbreaks. This means the infection rate was higher in some parts of the country than in others. If we have an accurate picture of this, we can combat the virus quickly and in a targeted manner.

vragen.vraag: Is this one of the apps that was announced?
vragen.antwoord: No, this is not an app. An anonymous contact tracing app is being developed so that people can find out if they may have been in close proximity to someone carrying coronavirus, and to advise them on what to do in that case. A home monitoring app will help the municipal health service (GGD) stay in touch with people with suspected or confirmed coronavirus infection.

vragen.vraag: Does the dashboard respect my privacy?
vragen.antwoord: Yes, the dashboard complies with privacy rules. The presented data cannot be traced back to individual people.

vragen.vraag: What conclusions can I draw based on the information on this dashboard?
vragen.antwoord: The dashboard gives insight in the development of the virus, but it is not possible draw any conclusions. However, the data on the dashboard is used by experts, such as RIVM researchers.

vragen.vraag: I can see that coronavirus is under control in my region. So why do the same measures apply here as in other regions?
vragen.antwoord: The situation in different regions can vary a lot, and the epidemic is much bigger in some regions than in others. But the virus can easily spread across the country and that’s why many measures apply nationwide. Sometimes, extra measures are taken in a specific region if there are many extra cases there. In the future we aim that the dashboard will make it possible to introduce measures that target specific regions or sectors.

vragen.vraag: I’ve found a technical vulnerability in the website. Where can I report this?
vragen.antwoord: We work together with the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC). Please notify them of the vulnerability as soon as possible using their form (https://www.ncsc.nl/contact/kwetsbaarheid-melden/cvd-meldingen-formulier) before making the issue publicly known. We will deal with your notification and resolve it as quickly as possible together with the NCSC.

vragen.vraag: Who can I contact with questions about coronavirus and COVID-19?
vragen.antwoord: Please call the public information number 0800-1351 from within the Netherlands (open between 8.00 and 20.00). From outside the Netherlands, call +31 20 205 1351.

vragen.vraag: Why do I find a different value for the total number of positively tested persons as shown on the site, if I add all the reported positively tested persons per safety region?
vragen.antwoord:
We calculate the increase in the number of positively tested persons by deducting  the current day’s cumulative number of positively tested persons reported from the cumulative number reported the day before. 
Any corrections to historical data, such as double counting, are processed by the RIVM on the day the error was discovered. This means the number of new cases reported for that day is lower than the actual number, but this is offset by the numbers being too high on previous days. Because of such corrections, it is possible for the current day’s cumulative number to be lower than the number for the day before. This is then depicted as 0 (zero) on the dashboard, as a negative number is confusing. This is why discrepancies arise when regional data is aggregated into national data. If you would use the negative values of the safety regions to calculate the daily number of positively tested persons, you would find the correct values.

regionaal_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.text: Number of admissions per day, averaged over the past three days.

regionaal_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.fold: Number of confirmed COVID-19 patients admitted to hospital per day. This value is an average of the reported admissions over the past three days.

regionaal_positief_geteste_personen.title: Positively tested persons
regionaal_positief_geteste_personen.text: Number of positively tested persons per 100.000 inhabitants per day.

regionaal_positief_geteste_personen.fold: This figure shows how many people per 100,000 inhabitants were reported yesterday as testing positive for COVID-19.

verantwoording.title: Explanation of the data presented
verantwoording.paragraaf: The dashboard presents a variety of data that give us an idea of how we are managing the COVID-19 epidemic. Here we explain how we arrive at this data.

cijfers.cijfer: Update of 11 August on the peak of the number of positively tested persons
cijfers.verantwoording:
Due to technical reasons, not all reports on infections could be sent from the municipal health services (GGDs) to the National Institute for Public Health and environment (RIVM). These later received reports were on the 9th en 10th of August added to the data. In total there were 160 later received reports, of which 9 on the 9th and 151 on the 10th of August.{{whitespace}}

These 160 later received reports were spread through the safety regions as follows:{{whitespace}}
Amsterdam-Amstelland: 8 
Flevoland: 30 
Friesland: 8
Groningen: 1
Hollands Midden: 26
Rotterdam-Rijnmond: 7
Midden- en West-Brabant: 27 
Zaanstreek-Waterland: 8
Zeeland: 23
Zuid-Limburg: 14
Gelderland-Midden: 7
Unknown: 1

cijfers.cijfer: Update of 31 July on the alert value for number of infectious people
cijfers.verantwoording: Originally, it was announced that an alert value would be developed for the number of infectious people. However, the modelling experts at the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) have advised us not to do this, as the number of infectious people is not based exclusively on measurable data but also on assumptions, about how long people remain infectious, for instance.

These figures are supplied daily as open data by the National Intensive Care Evaluation Registry [Stichting NICE]  (https://stichting-nice.nl/covid-19/public/new-intake/confirmed/). The source data refers to the previous 24 hours. The calculation of the ICU admissions is based on patients with a confirmed infection of the COVID-19 virus.{{whitespace}} From the source file, we calculate the average admissions over the past three days. Thus this does not include the number for the current day. The average is obtained by adding up each day’s values (the figures for one day, two days and three days ago), dividing the total by three and rounding off the answer to one decimal place.
This information has not yet been shared with the Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport and is therefore not available on the dashboard.

cijfers.cijfer: Nursing Homes: number of residents testing positive, number of homes with outbreaks, number of deaths.
cijfers.verantwoording: The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) provides the Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport with information about the COVID-19 situation in nursing homes every day. The data is delivered in JSON format. RIVM publishes this information on its website as a .PDF file at the same time that it is delivered to the ministry. The values in that file are copied directly onto the dashboard.

cijfers.cijfer: Nursing homes: number of infected locations
Number of patients who contact their GP for the first time because of symptoms associated with COVID-19

cijfers.verantwoording: In rioolwater kun je ziekteverwekkers zoals het nieuwe coronavirus meten omdat die met uitwerpselen (ontlasting) in het rioolwater komen. Onderzoekers testen eens per week rioolwater dat over 24 uur verzameld is. Dit onderzoek laat vrij snel zien hoeveel virusdeeltjes in het rioolwater zitten afkomstig uit uitwerpselen van besmette personen. Uit het huidige onderzoek kunnen nog geen conclusies worden getrokken. Het is de bedoeling dat het aantal meetpunten wordt uitgebreid van 28 naar meer dan 300 voor 1 september 2020. Pas als het onderzoek volledig loopt, kunnen hier conclusies aan worden verbonden. {{whitespace}} In de grafiek zie je op de Y-as het aantal virusdeeltjes in een milliliter rioolwater afkomstig van 28 locaties in Nederland. Op de X-as zie je de data waarop het materiaal is verzameld uit het rioolwater. De lijn geeft de hoeveelheid virusdeeltjes per milliliter rioolwater weer. De gevulde cirkels in de lijn geven aan op welk moment het genetisch materiaal voor de test is verzameld uit het rioolwater. Deze informatie wordt wekelijks (meestal op dinsdag) beschikbaar gesteld door het RIVM en als Excel-bestand aangeleverd bij het ministerie van VWS. Deze excel wordt omgezet naar een CSV om in te lezen. Het bronbestand rapporteert over weeknummers. De weeknummers uit het bestand worden omgezet naar de datum van de maandag van de betreffende week voor weergave op het dashboard. Het RIVM werkt toe naar het als open data beschikbaar van deze informatie.

The tiles on the dashboard show the term "value of" to indicate the date to which the number refers, while ‘obtained on’ is used to refer to the date when the information was received. The purpose of providing this information is to give users a better idea of how up-to-date the data is, which is especially relevant for retrospective indicators. For instance, RIVM publishes the reproduction number (R) once a week, but the most recent R is always for a date two weeks in the past. ‘Value of’ is followed by that date two weeks ago, and ‘obtained on’ by the date on which the most recent R was published (the current week).

This dashboard was developed in a short amount of time. So far, we have therefore not been able to publish the code for inputting the data, making the calculations and constructing open source .JSON files. However, this will be done soon. The web application code was published on [Github] on 5 June 2020 (https://github.com/minvws/nl-covid19-data-dashboard)

regionaal_rioolwater_metingen.title: Waste water testing
regionaal_rioolwater_metingen.text: Number of viral particles in one milliliter of wastewater, collected from 28 locations in the Netherlands. Over the next few weeks, the number of sampling locations will be increased to more than 300.
regionaal_rioolwater_metingen.datums: Value of {{dateOfReport}}. Obtained: {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
regionaal_rioolwater_metingen.fold: Wastewater contains human excrement that contains pathogens (viruses and bacteria that can make people sick). Once a week at each location, researchers test samples of wastewater collected over a period of 24 hours. These tests detect the presence of coronavirus particles in wastewater originating from the excrement of people with COVID-19. The research so far do not allow us to draw conclusions. The number of sampling points will be increased from the current 28 to more than 300. Only when testing is taking place on this larger scale, will it be possible to draw conclusions based on the findings.
regionaal_rioolwater_metingen.screen_reader_graph_content: {{value}} viral particles in one milliliter of wastewater, collected from 28 locations in the Netherlands.
regionaal_rioolwater_metingen.bar_chart_title: Last known value per RWZI location
regionaal_rioolwater_metingen.bar_chart_axis_title: Number of viral particles in milliliter waste water
regionaal_rioolwater_metingen.graph_average_label_text: Average value of all tested locations
